body:
@danbartl, FYI - any ideas?

It looks like the output is not a hierarchical data frame, but a pandas Series - that looks wrong.
we need to add tests for this, too

issue.title: [BUG] ensure all forecasting reducers are tested via the default test suite

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Currently, the forecasting reducers are not tested in the test suite, because `all_estimators` does not retrieve classes starting with an underscore `_`, and the reducer classes do start with an underscore.

The reducer classes do start with underscore, but are concrete, not abstract, so should have been tested.

This has led to undetected bugs and regression not covered, see https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3316

body:
reason for test failure is probably that this is not done correctly:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/2460
I suspect we currently do not test hierarchical scenarios for forecasters that claim to handle them genuinely.

That needs to be addressed in the tests.

issue.title: [ENH] test hierarchical forecasters with hierarchical data

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR enables a panel and a hierarchical scenario for forecasting, and applies it whenever the forecaster claims to deal with `Panel` or `Hierarchical` data natively, i.e., if `y_inner_mtype` contains a `Panel` or `Hierarchical` mtype.

This should detect the bug reported in https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3316 (and actually does)

Includes fixes for the following bugs detected:
* https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3324
* https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3326 (temporary fix of #3316)

issue.title: [ENH] remove hierarchical datatypes from recursive reduction forecasters

labels.name: bugfix
labels.description: Fixes a known bug or removes unintended behavior

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR removes hierarchical datatypes from recursive reduction forecasters as a temporary measure to address #3316.

Until #3316 is addressed at the root, this will allow the recursive forecasters to be applied to hierarchical data without raising an exception - what happens is simply naive vectorization, i.e., one model is fitted per unit/instance.

body:
Tests are fixed now and correctly pick up this issue, see #3321. Will temporarily fix this (forcing local pooling) via #3326.

Prototype on how we can easily switch between global and local pooling is in #3327 (though that is direct reduction).

@wregter, many apologies again for this, the tests did not catch the bug.

I coded up a recursive strategy now along the newer prototype design, hope this satisfies your requirements:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3333
still experimental, but perhaps what you were looking for - and feedback is appreciated!
(any feedback here, please: https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3224)

issue.title: [ENH] global/local recursive reduction prototype

labels.name: implementing framework
labels.description: Implementing frameworks for new learning tasks

labels.name: interfacing algorithms
labels.description: Interfacing existing algorithms/estimators for other packages

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Global/local recursive reduction prototype along the lines of https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3327.

Dependent on https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3327 as it uses a joint reduction mixin, refactored from https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3327.

Addresses https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3224 and #3316

issue.title: [BUG] make_reduction 'Level type mismatch' when fitting model

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
**Describe the bug**

I experienced this error when using make_reduction with any window size to fit and predict. When running `.predict`, it seems to be slicing indicies that are not in the test set. My date range for the test set goes from  2022-05-19 to 2022-05-25 but the error is with the date 2022-05-12, which is the the window_length number of days before the start day. The data is in hierarchal format


<br class="Apple-interchange-newline">

**To Reproduce**

```python

from xgboost import XGBRegressor

y_train, y_test, x_train, x_test= temporal_train_test_split(y_hat,x_new,test_size=7) # The week of 5/19 - 5/25 is the test

regressor = XGBRegressor(objective='reg:squarederror', random_state=42)
forecaster = make_reduction(regressor,window_length=7,strategy='recursive')

pipe = TransformedTargetForecaster(steps=[
    ("detrender", Deseasonalizer()),
    ("forecaster", forecaster)
])

pipe.fit(y=y_train,X=x_train)
y_pred = pipe.predict(fh=[1,2,3,4,5,6,7],X=x_test) # From 5-19 to 5-25

```

_Error message:_

**TypeError: Level type mismatch: 2022-05-12**

TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<command-1972184593868422> in <module>
      1 #fh = ForecastingHorizon()
----> 2 y_pred = forecaster.predict(fh=[1,2,3,4,5,6,7],X=x_test)
      3 

/databricks/python/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_base.py in predict(self, fh, X)
    323         # we call the ordinary _predict if no looping/vectorization needed
    324         if not self._is_vectorized:
--> 325             y_pred = self._predict(fh=fh, X=X_inner)
    326         else:
    327             # otherwise we call the vectorized version of predict

/databricks/python/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_sktime.py in _predict(self, fh, X)
     29         # all values are out-of-sample
     30         if fh.is_all_out_of_sample(self.cutoff):
---> 31             return self._predict_fixed_cutoff(
     32                 fh.to_out_of_sample(self.cutoff), **kwargs
     33             )
/databricks/python/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_sktime.py in _predict_fixed_cutoff(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha)
     63         """
     64         # assert all(fh > 0)
---> 65         y_pred = self._predict_last_window(
     66             fh, X, return_pred_int=return_pred_int, alpha=alpha
     67         )
/databricks/python/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/compose/_reduce.py in _predict_last_window(self, fh, X, return_pred_int, alpha)
    665             y_last, X_last = self._get_shifted_window()
    666         else:
--> 667             y_last, X_last = self._get_last_window()
    668 
    669         # If we cannot generate a prediction from the available data, return nan.

/databricks/python/lib/python3.8/site-packages/sktime/forecasting/base/_sktime.py in _get_last_window(self)
    126 
    127         # Get the last window of the endogenous variable.
--> 128         y = self._y.loc[start:cutoff].to_numpy()
    129 
    130         # If X is given, also get the last window of the exogenous variables.

**Expected behavior**

Perform a global forecast on all the hierarchical data.

**Additional context**

I'm trying to transform only the `y` target variable and leave the `x` data alone. Not sure if I'm using make_reduction when I'm not supposed to be or if there's an equivalent


**Versions**
<details>

System:
    python: 3.8.10 (default, Jun 22 2022, 20:18:18)  [GCC 9.4.0]
executable: /local_disk0/.ephemeral_nfs/envs/pythonEnv-e16893be-13e7-4812-b22f-c0d78b237332/bin/python
   machine: Linux-5.4.0-1086-azure-x86_64-with-glibc2.29

Python dependencies:
          pip: 21.0.1
   setuptools: 52.0.0
      sklearn: 1.1.2
       sktime: 0.13.1
  statsmodels: 0.12.2
        numpy: 1.21.6
        scipy: 1.6.2
       pandas: 1.2.4
   matplotlib: 3.4.2
       joblib: 1.0.1
        numba: 0.55.1
     pmdarima: 1.8.4
      tsfresh: None

</details>

<!-- Thanks for contributing! -->

issue.title: [ENH/BUG] extend recursive strategy in `make_reduction` to allow global pooling on panel data

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
Fixes https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/issues/3316
Introduces a new parameter to allow users to specify whether single models should be fit at the level of instances ("local") or at a global level (single model across instances). 

Open question: Should default be local or global?

Status: fully functional
